codex-list-item-declutter.task:
The search results list is visually overwhelming. Looking at the 'after search' state, there are too many competing visual elements per row. Fix these issues in the list item rendering:

1. TYPE BADGES (Command, Snippet, App) - These colored badges are too loud. Make them much more subtle: use a muted/dim text label instead of bright colored pill badges. They should be secondary information, not screaming for attention. The green 'Snippet', purple 'Snippet', orange 'App', yellow 'Command' badges need to become understated text labels with muted colors.

2. CATEGORY TEXT (e.g. 'Clipboard Variables', 'Clipboard Transformations') shown next to 'paste' - This metadata is too prominent. Either hide it entirely during search, or make it very dim/small so it doesn't compete with the item name.

3. TRIGGER/SHORTCUT TEXT (!cb, !quote, !code, !htmllink, !mdlink, !upper) - These trigger shortcuts shown as bordered pills are adding visual clutter. Make them more subtle - dim text, smaller, or only show on hover/focus.

4. ACTION VERB ('paste', 'open') - The action verb shown before category text adds noise. Hide it during search results or make it much more subtle.

5. CHARACTER MATCH HIGHLIGHTING - The bold yellow character highlighting scattered through item names (e.g. bold 'C', 'l', 'i', 'p' in 'Clipboard') is too aggressive. Use a subtler highlight - maybe just a slightly brighter text color or light underline rather than bold+color on each matched character.

6. DESCRIPTION TEXT - When items show a second line of description text (like truncated content previews), make sure it's properly dimmed and doesn't compete with the primary name.

The goal is: search results should look almost as clean as the no-search state, with type info available but not screaming. Think Raycast/Spotlight level of visual calm.

codex-chat-scroll.task: Fix broken scrolling and auto-scrolling in the AI chat prompt. When a large markdown response streams in (e.g. 'create a massive amount of random markdown'), the scroll gets completely stuck and the user cannot scroll. Investigate src/prompts/chat.rs for the scroll container and auto-scroll logic. The likely issues are: (1) auto-scroll-to-bottom fighting with user scroll attempts, (2) the scroll container not properly updating its content bounds when markdown content grows large, (3) possible layout thrashing where content size changes trigger re-layouts that reset scroll position. Look at how uniform_list or scroll containers are used, ensure scroll_to_bottom only fires when the user is already at the bottom (not when they've scrolled up), and ensure the scrollable area properly accommodates growing content. Run cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test after changes.

codex-emoji-picker.task:
Build a Raycast-style emoji picker as a native GPUI view, replacing the current AppleScript choose_from_list dialog. This is the main implementation task. Follow the patterns from clipboard history (render_builtins/clipboard.rs) closely.

## 1. AppView variant (src/main_sections/app_view_state.rs)
Add:
```rust
/// Showing emoji picker grid with category sections
EmojiPickerView {
    filter: String,
    selected_index: usize,
    selected_category: Option<crate::emoji::EmojiCategory>,
}
```

## 2. State fields on ScriptListApp
Find where ScriptListApp struct is defined (likely in src/main_sections/) and add:
```rust
emoji_scroll_handle: UniformListScrollHandle,
```
Initialize it in the constructor (::new or wherever other scroll handles are initialized) with UniformListScrollHandle::new().

## 3. Render module (NEW FILE: src/render_builtins/emoji_picker.rs)
Create this file following the clipboard.rs pattern exactly. It should be an impl ScriptListApp block.

### Layout model (define locally in this file):
```rust
#[derive(Clone)]
enum EmojiGridRow {
    Header { title: String, count: usize },
    Cells { emoji_indices: Vec<usize> },
}
```

### fn render_emoji_picker(&mut self, filter: String, selected_index: usize, selected_category: Option<EmojiCategory>, cx: &mut Context<Self>) -> AnyElement

Structure:
- Get tokens: let tokens = get_tokens(self.current_design); spacing, typography, visual
- Filter emojis using crate::emoji::search_emojis(&filter)
- If selected_category is Some, further filter by category
- Group filtered emojis by category, chunk each group into rows of 8 columns (fixed)
- Build Vec<EmojiGridRow> with Header rows between category groups
- Track which flat emoji index maps to which row/col for navigation

### Key handler (cx.listener):
Follow clipboard pattern:
- Route to actions dialog first (route_key_to_actions_dialog with a new ActionsDialogHost::EmojiPicker variant - add this to the ActionsDialogHost enum in app_view_state.rs)
- Escape: clear filter first, then go_back_or_close
- Cmd+W: close window
- Arrow keys: 2D grid navigation
  - Left/Right: move within row, wrap to adjacent row
  - Up/Down: move to same column in previous/next GridRow (skip Headers), clamp to row length
- Enter: copy selected emoji to clipboard, hide window, simulate paste (same pattern as clipboard history enter handler)
- Update selected_index in AppView and call cx.notify()

### Grid rendering:
Use uniform_list over the rows Vec:
- Header row: div with category name (muted text) + count, left-aligned, small font
- Cells row: div().flex().gap(px(4.0)) with fixed-size emoji cells
- Each cell: div().id(flat_index).size(px(36.0)).flex().items_center().justify_center().rounded(px(6.0))
  - Selected: .border_2().border_color(accent from theme)  
  - Hovered: .bg(theme.colors.ui.hover with some opacity)
  - Child: text with the emoji character, font_size around 22px
  - on_click handler: set selected_index, copy emoji, hide window, simulate paste
  - on_hover handler: set hovered_index + input_mode (same as clipboard)

### Header bar:
- Search input using shared gpui_input_state (same as clipboard)
- Right side: text showing selected category name or 'All' + emoji count

### Footer:
- Left: selected emoji character + name (e.g. '❤️ Red Heart')
- Right: 'Copy to Clipboard ↵' + 'Actions ⌘K'
Use PromptFooter component with appropriate config.

### Divider between header and content (same as clipboard)

## 4. Register include (src/render_builtins/mod.rs)
Add: include\!("emoji_picker.rs");

## 5. Wire execution (src/app_execute/builtin_execution.rs)
Replace the entire BuiltInFeature::EmojiPicker match arm. Remove the AppleScript choose_from_list call. Instead, transition to the new view:
```rust
builtins::BuiltInFeature::EmojiPicker => {
    logging::log("EXEC", "correlation_id=builtin-emoji-picker-start action=show-emoji-grid");
    self.filter_text = String::new();
    self.pending_filter_sync = true;
    self.pending_placeholder = Some("Search Emoji & Symbols...".to_string());
    self.current_view = AppView::EmojiPickerView {
        filter: String::new(),
        selected_index: 0,
        selected_category: None,
    };
    self.hovered_index = None;
    self.opened_from_main_menu = true;
    self.pending_focus = Some(FocusTarget::MainFilter);
    cx.notify();
}
```

## 6. Render dispatch
Find the main render match on self.current_view (search for other AppView variants being matched and rendered, e.g., ClipboardHistoryView) and add the EmojiPickerView case that calls self.render_emoji_picker(filter, selected_index, selected_category, cx).

## Key conventions:
- Use theme.colors.* for ALL colors, never hardcode rgb values
- Use ? or graceful error handling, never unwrap() in production code
- Match key variants: 'up' | 'arrowup', 'down' | 'arrowdown', 'enter' | 'Enter' | 'return', 'escape' | 'Escape'
- Call cx.notify() after state mutations
- Do NOT set opaque background - let vibrancy show through from Root
- Use tracing::{info,warn,error,debug} for logging (but the existing logging::log pattern is fine too)

Create the emoji picker render module as a NEW file: src/render_builtins/emoji_picker.rs

This file should contain an impl ScriptListApp block with one main function: render_emoji_picker.

Follow the exact pattern from src/render_builtins/clipboard.rs but adapted for a grid of emojis instead of a list.

### fn render_emoji_picker(&mut self, filter: String, selected_index: usize, selected_category: Option<crate::emoji::EmojiCategory>, cx: &mut Context<Self>) -> AnyElement

Structure:
1. Get design tokens: let tokens = get_tokens(self.current_design); let design_spacing = tokens.spacing(); let design_typography = tokens.typography(); let design_visual = tokens.visual();
2. Get theme colors (same pattern as clipboard.rs): text_primary, text_dimmed, ui_border from self.theme.colors
3. Filter emojis: use crate::emoji::search_emojis(&filter) to get filtered list. If selected_category is Some, further filter by .category == selected_category.
4. Build grid rows: Define a local enum:
   enum EmojiGridRow { Header { title: String, count: usize }, Cells { start_index: usize, count: usize } }
   Group filtered emojis by category (use .category field), create Header row + chunked Cells rows (8 per row) for each category.
5. Key handler: cx.listener that handles:
   - escape: if !self.clear_builtin_view_filter(cx) { self.go_back_or_close(window, cx); }
   - Cmd+W: self.close_and_reset_window(cx)
   - up/arrowup: move selected_index up by 8 (one row), clamp to 0
   - down/arrowdown: move selected_index down by 8, clamp to max
   - left/arrowleft: selected_index = selected_index.saturating_sub(1)
   - right/arrowright: selected_index = (selected_index + 1).min(filtered_len - 1)
   - enter/return/Enter: copy selected emoji to clipboard and close window (use cx.write_to_clipboard + self.close_and_reset_window)
   Always update the AppView::EmojiPickerView selected_index and call cx.notify()
6. Grid content: Use uniform_list over rows.len(), where each row renders either:
   - Header: div().px(px(design_spacing.padding_lg)).py(px(4.0)).text_sm().text_color(rgb(text_dimmed)).child(format!('{} {}', title, count))
   - Cells: div().flex().px(px(design_spacing.padding_lg)).gap(px(4.0)).children(emojis mapped to cells)
   Each cell: div().id(flat_emoji_index).w(px(36.0)).h(px(36.0)).flex().items_center().justify_center().rounded(px(6.0)).text_size(px(22.0)).cursor_pointer()
     - If selected: .border_2().border_color(rgb(self.theme.colors.accent.primary))
     - If hovered: .bg(rgba((self.theme.colors.ui.hover << 8) | 0x30))
     - on_click: copy emoji to clipboard, show HUD, close window
     - on_hover: update hovered_index
     - child: emoji.emoji string
7. Layout: div().flex().flex_col().w_full().h_full()
   .child(header with Input + emoji count)
   .child(divider)
   .child(grid content area with flex_1)
   .child(footer using PromptFooter with 'Copy' primary label)

Use self.emoji_scroll_handle for the uniform_list track_scroll.
Use self.focus_handle for track_focus.
Use self.gpui_input_state for the Input component.

Fix left/right arrow key navigation in the emoji picker grid. The root cause: GPUI's Input component consumes left/right arrow keys as MoveLeft/MoveRight cursor-movement actions BEFORE either the intercept_keystrokes handler or the on_key_down handler can process them. Up/down may work because single-line Input doesn't handle those.

The fix approach: In src/render_builtins/emoji_picker.rs, register on_action handlers for the editor movement actions (editor::actions::MoveLeft and editor::actions::MoveRight, or whatever the GPUI Input uses) on the emoji picker's outer div. These action handlers should perform grid navigation (decrement/increment selected_index) and call cx.stop_propagation() so the Input doesn't also move its cursor.

Alternative approach if the action registration is too complex: Instead of the Input component having focus, give focus to the outer div (which already has .track_focus(&self.focus_handle)). Then handle ALL key input in the on_key_down handler: arrow keys for grid navigation, printable characters to update the filter text programmatically via the gpui_input_state, backspace to delete. This prevents the Input from consuming any keys.

Key files and context:
- src/render_builtins/emoji_picker.rs: The render function with on_key_down handler (around lines 113-172). The outer div has .track_focus(&self.focus_handle) and .on_key_down(handle_key). Inside, it has an Input::new(&self.gpui_input_state).

codex-scheduler-security.task:
Fix 3 security issues in the scheduler system:

1. UNBOUNDED OUTPUT CAPTURE (critical): In src/main_entry/runtime_watchers_scheduler.rs AND src/main_entry/app_run_setup.rs, the scheduler uses child.wait_with_output() which buffers entire stdout/stderr in memory. A script can print indefinitely and OOM the app. Fix: Instead of wait_with_output(), pipe stderr only (set stdout to Stdio::null()), read stderr with a BufReader line by line, cap at 64KB max, then wait() for exit. Truncate any logged stderr to 4KB max. Apply this fix in BOTH files where wait_with_output is used for scheduled script execution.

2. CONCURRENCY LIMITING (critical): In src/scheduler/mod.rs scheduler_loop and the handler threads in runtime_watchers_scheduler.rs and app_run_setup.rs, there is no limit on concurrent scheduled script executions. Add a global concurrency limit: use an Arc<Semaphore> (from std::sync) or Arc<AtomicUsize> counter to limit concurrent scheduled runs to 4. Before spawning a bun process, check the counter; if at limit, log a warning and skip the run. Decrement after the process finishes.

3. STREAMING METADATA READ (major): In src/scripts/metadata.rs, extract_schedule_metadata_from_file uses fs::read_to_string which loads entire files. Only the first 30 lines are needed. Change to use File::open + BufReader + .lines().take(30) to avoid loading multi-MB files into memory.
codex-scheduler-security.notes: [auto] timed out after 600s — task too broad

codex-scheduler-output-cap.task:
Fix unbounded output capture in scheduled script execution. In BOTH src/main_entry/runtime_watchers_scheduler.rs AND src/main_entry/app_run_setup.rs, find where scheduled scripts are spawned and child.wait_with_output() is called. Replace wait_with_output() with a bounded approach:

1. Set stdout to Stdio::null() on the Command (we don't need it)
2. Set stderr to Stdio::piped()
3. After spawn, take stderr handle and read it with BufReader line by line
4. Cap total stderr to 64KB (count bytes, stop reading after limit)
5. Call child.wait() for exit status
6. When logging stderr on failure, truncate to first 4096 bytes

This prevents a malicious scheduled script from OOM-ing the app by printing endlessly. Apply the fix in BOTH files.

codex-metadata-streaming.task:
In src/scripts/metadata.rs, find the function extract_schedule_metadata_from_file which uses fs::read_to_string to load entire script files into memory. Only the first 30 lines are needed for metadata extraction. Replace fs::read_to_string with a streaming approach:

1. Use std::fs::File::open + std::io::BufReader
2. Read lines with .lines().take(30) 
3. Collect those lines into a string (joined with newline)
4. Pass that string to the existing extract_schedule_metadata function

This prevents multi-MB or multi-GB script files from being fully loaded just to read metadata comments in the first few lines.

scriptlet-template-escaping.task: Security fix: The format_scriptlet() function in src/scriptlets/mod.rs does raw str::replace() to substitute user inputs into shell scripts, enabling RCE via values like $(rm -rf ~). Implement a ScriptletDialect enum (Sh, Bash, Zsh, PowerShell, Cmd) and an escape_value(dialect, value) function with correct per-shell escaping: for sh/bash/zsh use single-quote wrapping with ' replaced by '"'"', for powershell single-quote with ' replaced by '', for cmd use double-quote wrapping with ^ escape for special chars. Reject NUL bytes in all cases. Apply escaping to both named {{variables}} and positional args in format_scriptlet(). Add unit tests for each dialect covering injection payloads like $(cmd), `cmd`, ; cmd, and strings with quotes. The project uses anyhow for errors, tracing for logging, and forbids unwrap() in production code.

secure-tempfiles.task: Security fix: Temp files for scriptlet execution are predictable (scriptlet-{pid}.sh), world-readable (0o755), and vulnerable to symlink/race attacks. In src/executor/scriptlet.rs, replace the manual temp file creation with tempfile::Builder for atomic random creation. Lock permissions to 0o700 for executable scripts or 0o600 for interpreter-fed scripts. Also fix command-string injection in open_terminal_with_command() in src/app_impl/execution_scripts.rs which concatenates raw tool + raw path without escaping — use proper argument passing instead of string concatenation. Add the tempfile crate to Cargo.toml if not already present. The project uses anyhow for errors, tracing for logging, and forbids unwrap() in production code. Use ? operator for error handling.

path-traversal-hardening.task: Security fix: Scriptlet paths from UI/config need canonicalization and base-dir constraint. In src/scriptlets/mod.rs, add path validation that rejects .. segments and enforces that resolved paths stay within the allowed scriptlet directories. Enforce a size limit of 2 MiB on scriptlet files to prevent parser DoS. In src/app_impl/execution_scripts.rs, harden execute_edit() and execute_open() to reject file://.. traversal and suspicious URL schemes (only allow file://, http://, https://). Use std::fs::canonicalize() for path resolution and compare against allowed base directories. The project uses anyhow for errors and tracing for logging. Never use unwrap() — use ? operator instead.

This prevents leaking tokens, credentials, and secrets from the parent environment to untrusted scriptlets. Add a comment explaining the security rationale. unify-applescript-escape.task: In src/utils/applescript.rs, the function escape_applescript_string() only escapes backslash and double-quote. AppleScript interprets newline, carriage return, and tab as control characters inside double-quoted strings. Strengthen the function to also escape these characters. Current code: input.replace('\\', "\\\\" ).replace('"', "\\\"" ). Replace with a chain that escapes backslash FIRST (critical for ordering), then double-quote, then newline (\n → \\n), carriage return (\r → \\r), and tab (\t → \\t). The function should become: input.replace('\\', "\\\\").replace('"', "\\\"").replace('\n', "\\n").replace('\r', "\\r").replace('\t', "\\t"). Also add a test: test_escape_applescript_string_escapes_control_chars that verifies a string containing newline, carriage return, and tab gets properly escaped. Do not change any other files. Run cargo check and cargo test to verify.

fix-execute-type-escape.task: In src/executor/scriptlet.rs, the function execute_type() (macOS cfg block) builds an AppleScript string with inline .replace('\\', "\\\\" ).replace('"', "\\\"" ) which misses newline/carriage-return/tab, allowing AppleScript injection from scriptlet type: values. Replace that inline escaping with a call to crate::utils::escape_applescript_string(text). The format\! call should become: format\!(r#"tell application \"System Events\" to keystroke \"{}\""#, crate::utils::escape_applescript_string(text)). Only change the #[cfg(target_os = "macos")] variant of execute_type. Do not change execute_paste, execute_submit, or the non-macos variant. Run cargo check to verify.

dedupe-builtin-applescript-escape.task: In src/app_execute/builtin_execution.rs, there is a private function applescript_escape() (around line 26-32, cfg(target_os = macos)) that duplicates crate::utils::escape_applescript_string(). Delete the applescript_escape function entirely. Then replace ALL occurrences of applescript_escape( in this file with crate::utils::escape_applescript_string(. The call sites include: applescript_list_literal function, choose_from_list, display_dialog/get_text_input, and quicklinks formatting. All call sites are inside cfg(target_os = macos) blocks which is fine since escape_applescript_string is not cfg-gated. Do not change any logic, only the import path. env-scrub-type-submit-osascript.task: In src/executor/scriptlet.rs, the execute_type() and execute_submit() functions spawn Command::new("osascript") without calling apply_scriptlet_environment_allowlist(). This leaks the full parent process environment (tokens, credentials) to osascript subprocesses running untrusted scriptlet content. Fix: In execute_type(), replace the inline Command::new("osascript").arg("-e").arg(&script).output() with a mutable cmd pattern: let mut cmd = Command::new("osascript"); cmd.arg("-e").arg(&script); apply_scriptlet_environment_allowlist(&mut cmd); let output = cmd.output().... Apply the identical pattern to execute_submit()'s osascript call. Also apply to execute_open() and execute_edit() if they have the same gap. Follow the pattern already used by execute_applescript() and execute_shell_scriptlet(). Do NOT change function signatures, do NOT modify apply_scriptlet_environment_allowlist itself, do NOT touch test code. Verify: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

quicklink-query-url-encode.task: In src/quicklinks/mod.rs, the expand_url() function does a raw string replacement: url_template.replace(QUERY_PLACEHOLDER, query). User-provided query text with special URL characters (spaces, &, #, =) is injected verbatim, enabling parameter injection or URL hijacking when passed to open::that(). Fix: Replace the expand_url function body to percent-encode the query using RFC 3986 unreserved characters (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, -, _, ., ~) as the safe set. Implementation: let encoded: String = query.bytes().map(|b| match b { b'A'..=b'Z' | b'a'..=b'z' | b'0'..=b'9' | b'-' | b'_' | b'.' | b'~' => (b as char).to_string(), _ => format\!("%{:02X}", b) }).collect(); url_template.replace(QUERY_PLACEHOLDER, &encoded). Update test test_expand_url_replaces_query_placeholder to expect 'rust%20gpui' instead of 'rust gpui'. Add new test test_expand_url_percent_encodes_special_chars verifying expand_url("https://example.com?q={query}", "a&b=c#d") returns "https://example.com?q=a%26b%3Dc%23d". Do NOT add new crate dependencies. Do NOT change the Quicklink struct. Verify: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

scrub-system-actions-env.task: In src/system_actions/mod.rs, the functions run_applescript(), run_applescript_with_output(), get_bundle_id_from_path(), open_system_settings_url(), and open_system_preferences_main() all spawn Command::new("osascript"/"mdls"/"open") without clearing the environment, leaking API keys and tokens to child processes. Fix: Add a private helper at the top of the file: const SYSTEM_CMD_ENV_VARS: [&str; 5] = ["PATH", "HOME", "TMPDIR", "USER", "LANG"]; fn scrub_command_env(cmd: &mut Command) { cmd.env_clear(); for key in SYSTEM_CMD_ENV_VARS { if let Some(val) = std::env::var_os(key) { cmd.env(key, val); } } }. Then modify run_applescript() to build let mut cmd = Command::new("osascript"); cmd.arg("-e").arg(script); scrub_command_env(&mut cmd); and use cmd.output(). Apply the same to run_applescript_with_output(), get_bundle_id_from_path() (mdls command), open_system_settings_url() (open command), and open_system_preferences_main() (open command). Do NOT change any function signatures, do NOT touch test code, do NOT modify AppleScript content. Verify: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

pid-file-permissions.task: In src/process_manager/mod.rs, write_main_pid() creates the PID file via File::create() with default 0o644 permissions, and persist_active_pids() creates active-bun-pids.json via OpenOptions with the same defaults. In write_main_pid(), after let mut file = File::create(&self.main_pid_path)?, add: #[cfg(unix)] { use std::os::unix::fs::PermissionsExt; let perms = std::fs::Permissions::from_mode(0o600); file.set_permissions(perms)?; }. In persist_active_pids(), after the OpenOptions open call, add the same block. Also in write_main_pid(), after the create_dir_all(parent)? call, set directory permissions to 0o700: #[cfg(unix)] { use std::os::unix::fs::PermissionsExt; let perms = std::fs::Permissions::from_mode(0o700); let _ = fs::set_permissions(parent, perms); }. Do NOT change function signatures. Do NOT modify test code. Verify: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

agent-exec-hardening.task: Security-harden src/agents/executor.rs. Three layers: (1) Add env_clear() + safe allowlist (PATH, HOME, TMPDIR, USER, LANG, TERM, SHELL, XDG_RUNTIME_DIR) to ALL 3 spawn functions (execute_agent, explain_agent, dry_run_agent) so child mdflow processes don't inherit parent secrets. Frontmatter _env values should be applied ON TOP of the scrubbed base. (2) Canonicalize agent.path and validate it resolves to a real .md file under the kit agents directory — reject path traversal. (3) Argv hardening: normalize variable keys by rejecting reserved mdflow system flags (quiet, context, env, command), reject control chars and newlines in values, and insert '--' before positional args to prevent option injection. Follow existing patterns in the codebase (see src/executor.rs which already has env allowlist scrubbing for scriptlet spawns). Use anyhow for errors, no unwrap() in production code, use tracing for logging.

codex-fallback-refactor-v2.task:
In src/executor/runner.rs, refactor the duplicated runtime fallback chains. Here is the exact plan:

STEP 1: Add these items ABOVE the execute_script_interactive function:

A struct RuntimeAttempt with fields: name: &'static str, label: String (for log messages like 'bun with preload'), cmd: String, args: Vec<String>.

A generic function:
fn run_fallback_chain<T>(
    attempts: &[RuntimeAttempt],
    start: &Instant,
    mut runner: impl FnMut(&str, &[&str], &str) -> Result<T, String>,
    script_path: &str,
) -> Option<T>

This function iterates attempts. For each attempt it:
- Calls logging::log("EXEC", &format!("Trying: {} {}", attempt.cmd, attempt.args.join(" ")))
- Calls logging::bench_log with the attempt name
- Calls runner(attempt.cmd, attempt.args as &[&str], script_path)
- On Ok: logs success with info!() including runtime=attempt.name, duration_ms, bench_log, logging::log("EXEC", &format!("SUCCESS: {}", attempt.label)), returns Some(result)
- On Err: logs debug!(error=%e, runtime=attempt.name, "Spawn attempt failed"), logging::log("EXEC", &format!("FAILED: {}: {}", attempt.label, e)), continues to next
- Returns None if all fail

STEP 2: Refactor execute_script_interactive() (~line 575). Build a Vec<RuntimeAttempt>:
- If is_typescript && sdk exists: push RuntimeAttempt { name: "bun", label: "bun with preload", cmd: bun_path, args: ["run", "--preload", sdk_str, path_str] }
- If is_typescript: push RuntimeAttempt { name: "bun", label: "bun without preload", cmd: bun_path, args: ["run", path_str] }
- If is_javascript: push RuntimeAttempt { name: "node", label: "node", cmd: node_path, args: [path_str] }
Then call run_fallback_chain with spawn_script as runner. Keep the existing final Err("No suitable runtime...") message if None.

STEP 3: Refactor execute_script() (~line 769). Build attempts similarly but with the blocking variants (kit first, then bun+preload, bun, node). Use run_command as runner. Keep existing final error text.

IMPORTANT: Must pass cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test. Never use unwrap() in non-test code. Use tracing macros only (info!, warn!, error!, debug!).

codex-gpui-cursor-internals.task: Investigate how GPUI (the framework this app uses) manages cursors internally. Does it override NSCursor? (2) Any CursorStyle enum handling — does GPUI set cursors on its own dispatch cycle? codex-event-dispatch-order.task: Investigate the mouse move event dispatch chain in this app. The cursor fix uses a two-phase approach: (1) inner elements call claim_cursor_pointer() in on_mouse_move, (2) root element calls apply_default_cursor() last in bubble phase. The cursor is STILL flickering, so something is setting the cursor AFTER apply_default_cursor(). Find: (1) The exact event dispatch order — trace from src/main_sections/render_impl.rs where apply_default_cursor is called, and verify it truly fires LAST. (2) Any after-event hooks or deferred callbacks that might reset cursors. (3) Whether GPUI runs any post-event cursor updates (like reset_cursor_style). (4) Check if there are multiple mouse_move event registrations on overlapping elements that could cause apply_default_cursor to run before all claims are processed. (5) Check if macOS cursorUpdate: is being called after our mouseMoved handler. Do NOT make any code changes — investigation only.

key-helper-and-arg-form.task:
Create a unified key-handler helper and refactor ArgPrompt + FormPrompt to use it. There are already two small helpers in src/render_prompts/arg/helpers.rs (key_preamble check and SDK shortcut match from commits bec692ae and d3c874b6). The full ~60-line key-handler preamble is still duplicated across 5 prompts (arg, form, editor, div, term). The pattern is: (1) hide_mouse_cursor (2) key_preamble early-return (3) toggle-actions shortcut (4) route_key_to_actions_dialog (5) check_sdk_action_shortcut + trigger_action_by_name.

Step 1: Create src/render_prompts/key_handler.rs with a PromptKeyPreambleCfg struct and handle_prompt_key_preamble generic function. The cfg struct has: is_dismissable: bool, stop_propagation_on_global_shortcut: bool, stop_propagation_when_handled: bool, host: ActionsDialogHost. The function takes closure hooks: pre_handle (runs after key_preamble, before toggle/routing), toggle_predicate + on_toggle_actions (Cmd+K toggling), on_actions_dialog_execute (action routing), allow_sdk_shortcuts (gating), on_sdk_shortcut (execution). It returns bool (true=handled). Flow: hide_mouse_cursor -> key_preamble -> pre_handle -> toggle check -> route_key_to_actions_dialog (Execute/Handled/NotHandled) -> SDK shortcut check. Each handled branch calls cx.stop_propagation() only if cfg.stop_propagation_when_handled is true. No logging inside the helper - logging stays in call-site closures.

Step 2: Wire key_handler.rs into the build. Check if src/render_prompts has a mod.rs — if so add mod key_handler and pub(crate) use. If the project uses include\!() for these files, add the include alongside others.

Step 3: Refactor src/render_prompts/arg/render.rs — replace the duplicated preamble block in handle_key (from hide_mouse_cursor through SDK shortcut check/return) with handle_prompt_key_preamble call. Config: is_dismissable:true, stop_propagation_on_global_shortcut:false, stop_propagation_when_handled:false, host:ActionsDialogHost::ArgPrompt. pre_handle returns false. toggle: Cmd+K. Also fix unwrap: replace 'actions.is_some() && \!actions.as_ref().unwrap().is_empty()' with 'actions.as_ref().map_or(false, |a| \!a.is_empty())'. After helper call, re-derive key/modifiers locals for the rest of the handler.

Step 4: Same refactor for src/render_prompts/form/render.rs with host:ActionsDialogHost::FormPrompt, same config flags.

Step 5: Run cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test. Fix any issues.

codex-calc-core.task:
Create a Raycast-style inline calculator feature for Script Kit GPUI. This is a Rust app using the GPUI framework. The project already depends on 'meval' crate for math evaluation.

TASK 1 — Create src/calculator.rs:
- Define 'pub struct CalculatorInlineResult { pub raw_input: String, pub normalized_expr: String, pub operation_name: String, pub value: f64, pub formatted: String, pub words: String }'
- Implement 'pub fn try_build(input: &str) -> Option<CalculatorInlineResult>' that:
  a) Calls looks_like_math() — returns false if input is empty, has no digits (except pi/e), has no operator (+−*/^%) or function name (sin/cos/tan/sqrt/abs/ln/log/exp/floor/ceil/round), or contains disallowed chars (quotes, colon, backslash). All alpha tokens must be in an allowlist: pi, e, sin, cos, tan, asin, acos, atan, sqrt, abs, ln, log, log10, exp, floor, ceil, round, min, max.
  b) Calls normalize_expression() — preprocesses: '10%' → '(10/100)', '×'→'*', '÷'→'/', '−'→'-', 'π'→'pi'
  c) Calls meval::eval_str() on the normalized expression. If error or non-finite result → return None.
  d) Calls infer_operation_name() — detect primary operation: 'Add' if +, 'Subtract' if -, 'Multiply' if *, 'Divide' if /, 'Power' if ^, 'Sine'/'Cosine'/etc for trig functions, 'Square Root' for sqrt, 'Calculate' as default.
  e) Calls format_value(f64) → Option<String>: reject non-finite, integer-ish (fract < 1e-12) → no decimal, extreme magnitude → scientific notation, else fixed decimal trimmed of trailing zeros.
  f) Calls words_for_formatted_number() — converts formatted string to English words: handle negative ('Negative ...'), integer part (ones/teens/tens/hundreds/thousands/millions/billions/trillions), decimal part ('Point' + digit words). Cap at ~12 decimal digits.
- Use tracing::debug for logging, never unwrap() in production code.
- Register the module in src/main.rs or src/lib.rs with 'pub mod calculator;'

TASK 2 — Add state field to src/main_sections/app_state.rs:
- Add field 'pub inline_calculator: Option<crate::calculator::CalculatorInlineResult>' to the main app struct (likely ScriptListApp or similar). Initialize as None.

TASK 3 — Hook into src/app_impl/filter_input_change.rs:
- In the handle_filter_input_change method, AFTER self.filter_text is updated and BEFORE cx.notify() / queue_filter_compute():
  Add: let new_calc = crate::calculator::try_build(&new_text); if self.inline_calculator != new_calc { self.inline_calculator = new_calc; }
- Derive PartialEq on CalculatorInlineResult for this comparison.
- When inline_calculator changes, invalidate grouped cache if such a method exists, and scroll to top.

IMPORTANT CONVENTIONS:
- Never use unwrap() or expect() in src/ (non-test code). Use ? or graceful handling.
- Use tracing::{info,warn,error,debug,trace} for logging.
- Use pub(crate) for cross-module internals.
- Run 'cargo check' after changes to verify compilation.

clipboard-monitor-image-blob-cache.task: In src/clipboard_history/monitor.rs, the clipboard monitor calls encode_image_as_blob(&image_data) even when compute_image_hash says the image is identical to the last one. This wastes RGBA→PNG compression, SHA-256, and blob disk I/O on every repeat copy. Fix by caching the blob key alongside the last image hash. Replace last_image_hash: &mut Option<u64> with a small struct like LastImageState { hash: u64, blob_key: String }. On new image: compute hash; if different, run encode_image_as_blob once; call add_entry; only after successful add_entry update the cached hash/blob-key. On same image: if you have a cached blob key, skip encode_image_as_blob entirely. Preserve retry semantics: DB failure should not advance the cached state; encode failure may keep the hash but must not create a bogus cached blob key. Use tracing macros instead of logging::log. Never use unwrap() in production code — use ? or graceful error handling. Verify with: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

clipboard-blobstore-io-safety.task: In src/clipboard_history/image.rs, the blob decode path does redundant disk work: decode_to_render_image for blob: content checks dimensions via get_blob_dimensions (which loads the blob) and then loads the same blob again to decode it — a double read per decode. Refactor so a blob is loaded once per operation. Add internal helpers like fn png_dims_from_bytes(png: &[u8]) -> Option<(u32,u32)> and fn decode_png_bytes_to_render_image(png: &[u8]) -> Option<Arc<RenderImage>>. Keep the public API stable. In src/clipboard_history/blob_store.rs, make store_blob atomic: write to a temp file in the same directory, then rename to {hash}.png. If destination already exists, delete temp and return Ok (idempotent). Never leave partially-written blobs. Use tracing macros instead of logging::log. Never use unwrap() in production code. Verify with: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

codex-notes-arrow-keys.task:
Fix up/down arrow key behavior in the notes window editor. Currently when pressing up/down arrow keys in the notes editor, the text cursor disappears instead of moving up/down one line at a time like a normal text editor. The notes editor likely has a keyboard event handler that intercepts arrow keys for list navigation or some other purpose, preventing normal text editor cursor movement.

Investigate the notes window code (likely in src/prompts/notes*.rs or similar) and find where keyboard events are handled. The issue is probably that up/down arrow key events are being consumed/intercepted before reaching the text editor component (likely a GPUI Editor or TextArea). Fix this so that:
1. Up arrow moves cursor up one line in the editor
2. Down arrow moves cursor down one line in the editor  
3. Shift+Up selects text upward line by line
4. Shift+Down selects text downward line by line
5. All other normal text editor keyboard behaviors work (Home, End, Cmd+A, etc.)

Look at how the notes window renders its editor component and how key events flow. The fix likely involves either:
- Removing/modifying a key event handler that intercepts arrow keys
- Letting the editor component handle arrow keys before the parent intercepts them
- Adding proper cursor movement logic if the editor is custom

Follow existing code patterns. Match keyboard key variants for both formats (e.g. 'up' | 'arrowup'). Use theme.colors.* not hardcoded colors. Use ? for error handling, never unwrap() in production code.

After fixing, run: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test
Then commit with a descriptive message and push.

codex-reset-state-on-show.task: Fix: When the main keyboard shortcut is pressed to open the main window, the user sees a flash of the previous state (e.g. clipboard history UI) before it resets to the default main window. The fix: before showing/focusing the main window in response to the global shortcut, the app must synchronously reset to the default main view state FIRST, then show the window. Look at how the global keyboard shortcut handler triggers showing the main window — likely in the global shortcut registration code or the show/toggle handler. Find where the window is made visible and ensure the app state (AppView) is reset to the default prompt/main view BEFORE the window becomes visible. Check app_impl.rs, the shortcut handler, and the show logic. The key insight is: state reset must happen BEFORE window show, not after. Also check if there is a 'show' message type handler in the protocol/message handling code. After making changes, run: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test. Then commit with a descriptive message.

codex-paste-sequential.task:
Implement a 'Paste Sequentially' built-in command for Script Kit GPUI, modeled after Raycast's 'Paste Sequentially' feature. This command should:

1. Show a UI where users can enter multiple text items (one per line or in separate fields).
2. When activated, each time the user pastes (Cmd+V or similar), it pastes the NEXT item from the list in sequence.
3. After the last item is pasted, it should cycle back or stop.

Follow the existing built-in command pattern:
- Add a 'PasteSequentially' variant to the BuiltInFeature enum (likely in src/built_in.rs or similar)
- Add the entry in get_builtin_entries() with name, description, shortcode
- Add the execute_builtin() match arm that transitions to the appropriate AppView
- Create the UI prompt/view component following existing patterns (render_prompts/ and prompts/ directories)
- Wire up clipboard integration to paste items one at a time sequentially

codex-file-thumbnail-fix.task:
Fix a borrow checker error in src/render_builtins/file_search.rs. The error is:

error[E0502]: cannot borrow *self as mutable because it is also borrowed as immutable
  --> src/render_builtins/file_search.rs:344
  312: let display_indices = &self.file_search_display_indices; (immutable borrow)
  344: self.ensure_file_search_preview_thumbnail(selected_file.as_ref(), cx); (mutable borrow)
  484: display_indices is used later

The fix: Move the call to ensure_file_search_preview_thumbnail() BEFORE the line that borrows self.file_search_display_indices. The selected_file can be computed from cached_file_results[selected_index] independently without display_indices. Extract the selected_file computation first, call ensure_file_search_preview_thumbnail, THEN borrow display_indices.

Alternative: Clone the display_indices before the mutable borrow: let display_indices = self.file_search_display_indices.clone();

After fixing the borrow checker error, run: cargo check && cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings && cargo test

If clippy or test errors remain, fix them too. Then commit with message: 'feat(file-search): add image thumbnail preview with safety guards'

Key rules:
- No unwrap() in production code, only in tests
- Use theme.colors.* for text colors, never hardcode rgb values
- Call cx.notify() after state mutations
